After adding water, cover with a lid. When the water boils, it can splash up and cause issues, so covering it prevents mess and lets it cook evenly and quietly.
You might wonder how much water to add – break the dried red chilies and add water (repeats phrase multiple times).

instruction: Cover the pot with a tight-fitting lid. Cook on low heat for 15–20 minutes until the rice is fully cooked and the water is absorbed.

transcript_segments.text: The water is just right now. Time to put it on *dum* (slow steam cooking). I’ve added 3 tablespoons of ghee. Cover with banana leaf if available, then seal with foil.

instruction: Turn off the heat and let the biryani rest, covered, for 10 minutes to allow flavors to settle.

transcript_segments.text: Preheat an old dosa tawa (griddle), place the biryani pot on top, and cook on medium-low flame for 20 minutes. Then turn off the flame and leave it for another 10 minutes.

The rice is fluffy, perfectly cooked and separate. It looks amazing and is perfect to serve. You can pair it with mango pickle, brinjal curry, fried chilies, and dalcha.

instruction: Serve hot with onion raita or brinjal gravy. Enjoy the distinct, spicy-tangy flavors of Dindigul biryani.
